author: sky.cactus
content: It is (I believe) intentionally not formalized.  It is incredibly difficult to capture an informal system of governance compared to a formal system of governance.

author: sky.cactus
content: Formalizing it gives people a clear attack vector, while informal governance means that anytime someone tries to capture it the "rules" can change (because they were never defined).  Like picking up water vs picking up a rock.  The water will just reform over your hand if you try to carry it away, while the rock will rigidly stay in its original shape which makes it easier to carry away.

author: sky.cactus
content: Of course, this same property makes it incredibly hard to actually get anything done.  üòñ  Often we *do* want to "move the water", and this is very hard without a formal system of governance.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Can you please define what you mean by "capture" here?

author: sky.cactus
content: Meaning someone or some group, other than the intended person/group, seizes control of the power that the system of governance wields.

author: sky.cactus
content: In this case, the "intended person/group" is "all of the people who make up the Ethereum ecosystem" ideally, though I'm certain we don't currently hit that ideal we do our best to get *close* to that.
